question: [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Guardian Authority] Who can create guardian oracles, and can an attacker create their own guardian oracle to sign attestations for their controlled oracles? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Multiple Guardians] If multiple guardians exist in guardian_queue, can an attacker selectively choose a compromised guardian to sign attestations? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Attestation Overflow] Can an attacker repeatedly call actuate() to overflow the attestation count or storage, causing DoS or unexpected behavior? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Duplicate Attestations] At line 109, is there validation to prevent adding duplicate attestations from the same guardian for the same secp256k1_key? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Attestation Timestamp Mismatch] The attestation is created with timestamp_seconds * 1000 at line 107, but is this consistent with the validation at line 73? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Valid Count Manipulation] At line 120, valid_attestation_count is retrieved - can an attacker manipulate oracle state to inflate this count before min_attestations check? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Min Attestations Bypass] If queue.min_attestations() returns 0 or a very small value, can an oracle be enabled with insufficient attestations at line 121? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Race Condition] Between checking valid_attestation_count at line 120 and calling enable_oracle at line 123, can the count change due to reentrancy or concurrent calls? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Attestation Removal] If attestations can be removed from oracle state elsewhere, can an attacker enable an oracle then remove attestations to bypass future checks? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Expiration Calculation] At line 122, expiration time is calculated as current time + validity length - can this overflow or create an expiration time in the distant past/future? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Oracle Already Enabled] If oracle.enable_oracle() is called at line 123 when oracle is already enabled, does it overwrite existing valid configuration with potentially malicious mr_enclave? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [MR Enclave Validation] The mr_enclave parameter is passed directly to enable_oracle at line 123 without validation - can an attacker enable oracle with incorrect enclave measurement? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Key Substitution] The secp256k1_key used at line 123 comes from user input - can an attacker enable oracle with a different key than what was attested by guardians? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Validity Length Manipulation] If queue.oracle_validity_length_ms() returns a very large value, can oracles remain enabled indefinitely even with compromised keys? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Multiple Enable Calls] Can an attacker repeatedly call actuate to re-enable an oracle multiple times, potentially emitting false AttestationResolved events? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Event Data Integrity] The AttestationCreated event at lines 112-118 uses clock.timestamp_ms() - can this differ from the attestation timestamp, creating misleading events? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Event Spam] Can an attacker spam AttestationCreated events by repeatedly calling actuate() with valid but unnecessary attestations? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Resolution Event Timing] The AttestationResolved event at lines 126-131 is emitted only when threshold is reached - can this be manipulated to hide oracle enablement? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Event Field Mismatch] Are the secp256k1_key values in events at lines 115 and 128 guaranteed to match the key used in oracle state? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: run()] [Validation Bypass] Can an attacker directly call actuate() without going through validate() if actuate() is exposed through other entry points? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: run()] [State Consistency] Between validate() call at lines 145-154 and actuate() call at lines 155-163, can oracle/queue/guardian state change causing validation-time checks to be invalidated? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: run()] [Reentrancy] Can an attacker exploit reentrancy between validate() and actuate() calls to manipulate oracle state? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: run()] [Parameter Forwarding] All parameters are forwarded from run() to both validate() and actuate() - can parameter mutations in validate() affect actuate() behavior? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Access Control] The validate() function is public - can external contracts call it to verify signatures without going through proper attestation flow? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/oracle/oracle_attest_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Mutable Reference] Oracle is passed as &mut at line 44 to validate() which should be read-only - why is mutable access needed and can this be exploited? (Medium)
